option.label: ACK scan
option.short_desc: Send probes with the ACK flag set. Ports will be marked "filtered" or "unfiltered". Use ACK scan to map out firewall rulesets.

option.label: FIN scan
option.short_desc: Send probes with the FIN bit set. FIN scan can differentiate "closed" and "open|filtered" ports on some systems.

option.label: Maimon scan
option.short_desc: Send probes with the FIN and ACK bits set. Against some BSD-derived systems this can differentiate between "closed" and "open|filtered" ports.

option.label: Null scan
option.short_desc: Send probes with no flags set (TCP flag header is 0). Null scan can differentiate "closed" and "open|filtered" ports on some systems.

option.label: TCP SYN scan
option.short_desc: Send probes with the SYN flag set. This is the most popular scan and the most generally useful. It is known as a "stealth" scan because it avoids making a full TCP connection.

option.label: TCP connect scan
option.short_desc: Scan using the connect system call. This is like SYN scan but less stealthy because it makes a full TCP connection. It is the default when a user does not have raw packet privileges or is scanning IPv6 networks.

option.label: Window scan
option.short_desc: Same as ACK scan except that it exploits an implementation detail of certain systems to differentiate open ports from closed ones, rather than always printing "unfiltered" when a RST is returned.

option.label: Xmas Tree scan
option.short_desc: Send probes with the FIN, PSH, and URG flags set, lighting the packets up like a Christmas tree. Xmas tree scan can differentiate "closed" and "open|filtered" ports on some systems.

option.label: UDP scan
option.short_desc: Scan UDP ports. UDP is in general slower and more difficult to scan than TCP, and is often ignored by security auditors.

option.label: IP protocol scan
option.short_desc: Scan IP protocols (TCP, ICMP, IGMP, etc.) to find which are supported by target machines.

option.label: List scan
option.short_desc: Do not scan any targets, just list which ones would be scanned (with reverse DNS names if available).

option.label: No port scan
option.short_desc: Skip the port scanning phase. Other phases (host discovery, script scan, traceroute) may still run.

option.label: SCTP INIT port scan
option.short_desc: SCTP is a layer 4 protocol used mostly for telephony related applications. This is the SCTP equivalent of a TCP SYN stealth scan.

option.label: SCTP cookie-echo port scan
option.short_desc: SCTP is a layer 4 protocol used mostly for telephony related applications.

option.label: Paranoid
option.short_desc: Set the timing template for IDS evasion.

option.label: Sneaky
option.short_desc: Set the timing template for IDS evasion.

option.label: Polite
option.short_desc: Set the timing template to slow down the scan to use less bandwidth and target machine resources.

option.label: Normal
option.short_desc: Set the timing template to not modify the default Nmap value.

option.label: Aggressive
option.short_desc: Set the timing template for faster scan. Used when on a reasonably fast and reliable network.

option.label: Insane
option.short_desc: Set the timing template for the fastest scan. Used when on a fast network or when willing to sacrifice accuracy for speed.

option_check.label: Enable all advanced/aggressive options
option_check.short_desc: Enable OS detection (-O), version detection (-sV), script scanning (-sC), and traceroute (--traceroute).

option_check.label: Operating system detection
option_check.short_desc: Attempt to discover the operating system running on remote systems.

option_check.label: Version detection
option_check.short_desc: Attempt to discover the version number of services running on remote ports.

option_check.label: Idle Scan (Zombie)
option_check.short_desc: Scan by spoofing packets from a zombie computer so that the targets receive no packets from your IP address. The zombie must meet certain conditions which Nmap will check before scanning.

option_check.label: FTP bounce attack
option_check.short_desc: Use an FTP server to port scan other hosts by sending a file to each interesting port of a target host.

option_check.label: Disable reverse DNS resolution
option_check.short_desc: Never do reverse DNS. This can slash scanning times.

option_check.label: IPv6 support
option_check.short_desc: Enable IPv6 scanning.

option_check.label: Don't ping before scanning
option_check.short_desc: Don't check if targets are up before scanning them. Scan every target listed.

option_check.label: ICMP ping
option_check.short_desc: Send an ICMP echo request (ping) probe to see if targets are up.

option_check.label: ICMP timestamp request
option_check.short_desc: Send an ICMP timestamp probe to see if targets are up.

option_check.label: ICMP netmask request
option_check.short_desc: Send an ICMP address mask request probe to see if targets are up.

option_check.label: ACK ping
option_check.short_desc: Send one or more ACK probes to see if targets are up. Give a list of ports or leave the argument blank to use a default port.

option_check.label: SYN ping
option_check.short_desc: Send one or more SYN probes to see if targets are up. Give a list of ports or leave the argument blank to use a default port.

option_check.label: UDP probes
option_check.short_desc: Send one or more UDP probes to see if targets are up. Give a list of ports or leave the argument blank to use a default port.

option_check.label: IPProto probes
option_check.short_desc: Send one or more raw IP protocol probes to see if targets are up. Give a list of protocols or leave the argument blank to use a default list

option_check.label: SCTP INIT ping probes
option_check.short_desc: Send SCTP INIT chunk packets to see if targets are up. Give a list of ports or leave the argument blank to use a default port.

option_check.label: Script scan
option_check.short_desc: Use the Nmap Scripting Engine to gain more information about targets after scanning them.

option_check.label: Scripts to run
option_check.short_desc: Run the given scripts. Give script names, directory names, or category names. Categories are "safe", "intrusive", "malware", "discovery", "vuln", "auth", "external", "default", and "all". If blank, scripts in the "default" category are run.

option_check.label: Script arguments
option_check.short_desc: Give arguments to certain scripts that use them. Arguments are <name>=<value> pairs, separated by commas. Values may be Lua tables.

option_check.label: Trace script execution
option_check.short_desc: Show all information sent and received by the scripting engine.

option_check.label: Excluded hosts/networks
option_check.short_desc: Specifies a comma-separated list of targets to exclude from the scan.

option_check.label: Exclusion file
option_check.short_desc: Specifies a newline-, space-, or tab-delimited file of targets to exclude from the scan.

option_check.label: Target list file
option_check.short_desc: Reads target list specification from an input file.

option_check.label: Scan random hosts
option_check.short_desc: Option to choose targets at random. Tells Nmap how many IPs to generate. 0 is used for a never-ending scan.

option_check.label: Ports to scan
option_check.short_desc: This option specifies which ports you want to scan and overrides the default.

option_check.label: Fast scan
option_check.short_desc: Only scan ports named in the nmap-services file which comes with Nmap (or nmap-protocols file for -sO).

option_check.label: Use decoys to hide identity
option_check.short_desc: Send fake decoy probes from spoofed addresses to hide your own address. Give a list of addresses separated by commas. Use RND for a random address and ME to set the position of your address.

option_check.label: Set source IP address
option_check.short_desc: Specify the IP address of the interface you wish to send packets through.

option_check.label: Set source port
option_check.short_desc: Provide a port number and Nmap will send packets from that port where possible.

option_check.label: Set network interface
option_check.short_desc: Tells Nmap what interface to send and receive packets on.

option_check.label: Extra options defined by user
option_check.short_desc: Any extra options to add to the command line.

option_check.label: Set IPv4 time to live (ttl)
option_check.short_desc: Set the IPv4 time-to-live field in sent packets to the given value.

option_check.label: Fragment IP packets
option_check.short_desc: Causes the requested scan (including ping scans) to split up TCP headers over several packets.

option_check.label: Verbosity level
option_check.short_desc: Print more information about the scan in progress. Open ports are shown as they are found as well as completion time estimates.

option_check.label: Debugging level
option_check.short_desc: When even verbose mode doesn't provide sufficient data for you, debugging level is available to show more detailed output.

option_check.label: Packet trace
option_check.short_desc: Print a summary of every packet sent or received.

option_check.label: Disable randomizing scanned ports
option_check.short_desc: Scan ports in order instead of randomizing them.

option_check.label: Trace routes to targets
option_check.short_desc: Trace the network path to each target after scanning. This works with all scan types except connect scan (-sT) and idle scan (-sI).

option_check.label: Max Retries
option_check.short_desc: Try sending a probe to each port no more than this many times before giving up.

option_check.label: Max time to scan a target
option_check.short_desc: Give up on a host if it has not finished being scanning in this long. Time is in seconds by default, or may be followed by a suffix of 'ms' for milliseconds, 's' for seconds, 'm' for minutes, or 'h' for hours.

option_check.label: Max probe timeout
option_check.short_desc: Wait no longer than this for a probe response before giving up or retransmitting the probe. Time is in seconds by default, or may be followed by a suffix of 'ms' for milliseconds, 's' for seconds, 'm' for minutes, or 'h' for hours.

option_check.label: Min probe timeout
option_check.short_desc: Wait at least this long for a probe response before giving up or retransmitting the probe. Time is in seconds by default, or may be followed by a suffix of 'ms' for milliseconds, 's' for seconds, 'm' for minutes, or 'h' for hours.

option_check.label: Initial probe timeout
option_check.short_desc: Use the time given as the initial estimate of round-trip time. This can speed up scans if you know a good time for the network you're scanning.

option_check.label: Max hosts in parallel
option_check.short_desc: Scan no more than this many hosts in parallel.

option_check.label: Min hosts in parallel
option_check.short_desc: Scan at least this many hosts in parallel.

option_check.label: Max outstanding probes
option_check.short_desc: Never allow more than the given number of probes to be outstanding at a time. May be set to 1 to prevent Nmap from sending more than one probe at a time to hosts.

option_check.label: Min outstanding probes
option_check.short_desc: Try to maintain at least the given number of probes outstanding during a scan. Common usage is to set to a number higher than 1 to speed up scans of poorly performing hosts or networks.

option_check.label: Max scan delay
option_check.short_desc: Do not allow the scan delay (time delay between successive probes) to grow larger than the given amount of time. Time is in seconds by default, or may be followed by a suffix of 'ms' for milliseconds, 's' for seconds, 'm' for minutes, or 'h' for hours.

option_check.label: Min delay between probes
option_check.short_desc: Wait at least the given amount of time between each probe sent to a given host. Time is in seconds by default, or may be followed by a suffix of 'ms' for milliseconds, 's' for seconds, 'm' for minutes, or 'h' for hours.
